work.p: This manuscript was created when Whitman clipped it from the longer manuscript poem "Pictures," which was first published posthumously in 1925. The first several lines of "Pictures" (not including this line) were revised and published as "My Picture-Gallery" in The American in October 1880.

titleStmt.title: And here is the great
a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript fragment was originally the top of a page numbered "56" in the manuscript poem "Pictures," which Whitman probably created between 1855 and 1860 but left unpublished at his death. "Pictures" was first published posthumously in 1925. The description is probably of the Leonid meteor storm that occurred on the night of November 12–13, 1833.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: "Meteors" (1853)
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

revisionDesc.change: altered wording of date note based on Ken's review
separated out loc.00027, loc.00114, and loc.00124; checked; corrected

body.l:
And here is the great Meteor‑
Shower, the night, 12th‑13th
of the Eleventh Month, Year 58 of
The States,

See you! it is between midnight
and morning—See, the wondrous
spectacle of the meteors!

See! myriads, in all directions,
overhead—some with long‑
shining trains,

See, sSome are rolling over each
other, like water poured out
and running,

Those lLeaping, silent, white appa‑
ritions of the heavens,— of the
night.
